review_title: Best place to work for a student
job_title: Community Service Officer in Pomona, CA
pros:
- extremely flexible hours to fit a students life with schedules made by students for students with final exams kept in mind. 
- highly supportive team that always has your back even in the most stressful of situations
- gain real world experience to deal with conflicts that other jobs will rarely ever teach you.
- great place to mature for freshmen’s 
- get to know your campus inside and out like no other student can.
cons:
- moderate safety risk / employment hazard.
- daily risk of confrontation with guests of campus who don’t get their way.
- must have high integrity 
- high level of professionalism is required.

pros: Get to be a part of a positive and enriching environment that aides new students through their introduction to a new and transitional phase in their life.
cons: Environment can be a bit too politically correct, which is expected in college communities but this  status quo that is upheld at Cal Poly Pomona tends to overshadow the student experience by putting emphasis on the wrong things.

review_title: the campus offers great benefits, but there is little chance for upward mobilty.
pros: Cal Poly is a beautiful campus and most of the faculty and staff here are great people as well. but the climate of education is changing drastically.
cons:
Management is no longer advocating on behalf of students and delivering all of the counseling and resources necessary for a successful completion of a degree seeking student.  The primary concern is the profit margin!  
The university is largely understaffed we are finding that the preferred student is one who can navigate the website and self identify issues and resolutions vs. being able to visit the Registrar's Office for direction and/or an academic counselor or evaluator for suggestions on university policies that could successfully impact their experience.
The university president delivered his weekle newsletter this week and praise CPP for delivering graduates who are among the highest paid starting salaries in the nation, however it's staff is grossly underpaid and overworked. Management is no longer advocating on behalf of students and delivering all of the counseling and resources necessary for a successful completion of a degree seeking student.  The primary concern is the profit margin!  
The university is largely understaffed we are finding that the preferred student is one who can navigate the website and self identify issues and resolutions vs. being able to visit the Registrar's Office for direction and/or an academic counselor or evaluator for suggestions on university policies that could successfully impact their experience.
The university president delivered his weekle newsletter this week and praised CPP for delivering graduates who are among the highest paid starting salaries in the nation, however it's staff is grossly underpaid and overworked. The name of the game here is to understaff and defer from promoting from within for 2 reasons:
1) Keeping salaries low campus wide, bringing an outside employee reduces benefit costs and continues entry level salaries for whatever department one is interested in.  2) The "new hire" is unaware of the lack of upward mobilty, makes the transition much easier.

pros: Teaching young adults can be very enjoyable, it keeps an individual current, is always challenging, and you are constantly learning new technologies and information. You are autonomous and can be creative getting others to learn. You have flexible time during summers.
cons: Teaching involves long hours to prepare for class.  It can be challenging to inspire young adults to prepare for class and a good teacher is always needing to try new approaches to keep students enthused for learning.

pros: the best part of working for ASI Pomona you  make great conncections with others from different departments.
cons: When working for certain departments sometimes your not really appreciated by your leaders in a correct manner.

review_title: rewarding. hands on experience puts graduates ahead of the competition.
pros: experience and resume! no travel requirement while tacking classes and very flexible with scheduling. Great place to advance in career
cons: as a student, i cant wait to graduate simple because of the increase of statewide tuition and budget cuts. i have been lucky enough to avoid getting into any debt while studying and working here, but i still cannot wait to declare independence.

pros:
You get a lot of exposure to the classic work environment, some coordinators, namely the Fitness and Operations coordinators, are supportive in helping you build your resume and giving you job experience; they let some student employees conduct interviews, write proposals and generally give them a lot of experience.

 Having said that, these tasks are usually restricted to higher ranking student staff, which brings up the point there is tons of room for upward mobility working for this facility. The lower tier jobs are either being a Fitness Attendant, Member Services Attendant or Adventures staff member which make $10/hr. Above that are AOPs, Assistant Operations Supervisors. They essentially run the facility and help keep it moving smoothly. 

Some AOP staff members have complained that they are given too much responsibility for the amount of pay they are given $12/hr, which is true. But ultimately, the job and leadership experience both of which look phenomenal on a resume are well worth the responsibility and little pay. Typically the coordinator who is the boss of the AOPs likes to hire new AOPs from already present staff, namely Member Services, but it is possible to be hired as an AOP upon initial hiring.

Above AOPs are the student supervisors of Member Services and Fitness. These student supervisors report 
to the adult coordinators of that particular section (i.e. Fitness Coordinator, Member Services Coordinator). They monitor the student staff and make sure they are doing their jobs correctly, and report their findings to their assigned coordinator. They are also responsible for doing office work. 

They work around your student schedule; you give them your availability and they assign you shifts around it. You can work a maximum of $20/week.  And you additionally get paid for attending staff meetings.
cons:
As previously stated, you are expected of a lot working at Campus Recreation and the pay to some may not seem fair. However, if you value gaining work experience, it is well worth it. 

When you first join Campus Recreation, there will likely be a staff wide meeting within the first few weeks of you getting hired and the coordinators are seemingly very welcoming and "family" oriented. This is mainly a ploy to increase worker morale. They ultimately do not really care about you. You are dispensable, there are hundreds of students that could take your job, and they know that. Most of the coordinators do not go out of their way to help you, and recently there has been a sudden influx of terminations and re-hires. To secure your position I recommend doing a lot of "sucking up", befriending your coordinator and supervisor, visiting their office to chat, ect.

review_title: The campus is not only a great contribution to the the students, but also the faculty and staff who work there.
pros: The staff/faculty in the biological department is very positive and supportive.
cons: If you work for a specific department, you will have a difficult time meeting individuals from other disciplines.

review_title: Working at Cal Poly Pomona has been like crashing onto a brick wall.
pros: One of the best reasons to work at Cal Poly Pomona are the benefits. The other reason is the 4-10 schedule that we get during summer time (this hasn't always been the case and has just been done for these past two years now). One other reason is that it is very laid back and relaxed environment.
cons: Much of the employees at Cal Poly are not qualified to do the job they are hired for, since employment here is usually given within the company and most employees here have never had any other job except the one here at Cal Poly Pomona. There is a large lack of professionalism by the employees that can be attributed, again, to their lack of experience working at other companies/organizations. Management is mostly made up of people with no experience in their field and usually is comprised of faculty who have failed at being good professors, or lacked enthusiasm to continue teaching. If not, they are workers who have worked here since their first job and have made enough friends to with other management and staff that they get moved up for their friendship (this is very common). I got my job here fortunately because the other people who where part of the search pool had no experience whatsoever, and, very probable too, because I also knew a couple of the people on the search committee. I am actually one of the very few people who have came into Cal Poly Pomona with experience working in other environments.

review_title: IT Student Assistant position at Cal Poly Pomona
job_title: IT Student Assistant in Pomona, CA
pros: Very flexible schedule for students enrolled at Cal Poly Pomona. Great, enthusiastic staff to work alongside. Gave me the experience and confidence needed to start my career.
cons: There were very few downsides to this position, at most I could say that a few of my fellow Student Assistants weren't as enthusiastic as they could have been, but that by no fault of the IT staff.

review_title: The best department and employer at Cal Poly
job_title: Physics Stockroom Aid in Pomona, CA
pros:
The Pros of working at the Physics department-primarily their stockroom- for me were: 
They work around one's schedule/class schedule and care about making sure that you are able to maintain a life outside work. 
They keep you busy, but don't overwork you. 
They allow for a lot of personal growth and development.
cons:
Certain supervisors can be slavedrivers. 
The instructors can be unnecessarily rude at times and have unreasonable expectations at times.

pros: They have great benefits if you can get enough units to teach each quarter and it's a pretty laid back atmosphere for lecturers, not as much so recently bc of cuts
cons: Bc of the economy in CA, they have been cutting classes, which not only affects my salary, but also I see the impact on students trying to finish their education in less then 5 years.

Very little tax is taken out of your bi weekly pay.  Supervisor does a good job hiring people that get along with each other.
cons: Unfortunately the pay is at minimum wage but hardly a con since your primary focus is your education.

cons: It gets really busy because their are a lot of students who enjoy getting coffee during school hours. It can be rigorous.

pros: Beautiful campus.  Love working with students!!
cons: The Student Affairs administration is a mess.  There is a lot of transitions right now and everyone on top is just fighting for their own power.  Though the term "student-focused" hangs on their mouths all the time, they do not prioritize students' safety and welfare as top priorities.

pros: The excitement of students learning new skills and abilities. The ability for students to directly apply concepts from lecture into lab assignments.
cons: The administration is not organized and creates tremendous pressure for faculty to make semester conversion changes. The result is a lack of foresight and ability to plan for the future because of short timelines and lack of trust in faculty to be responsible.

review_title: Fulfilling. It allowed me to have some decent work experience while in school!
pros: Is flexible with school schedules; easy-going management; despite being knee-deep in bureaucracy, the work environment is open to new and creative ideas.
cons: Affected by furloughs and budget cuts, so therefore the pay isn't great. However, this greatly depends on the position and department you are located in.

job_title: Front Desk Assistant in Pomona, CA
pros:
It's very convenient to work where you live and go to school.
Staff is very friendly and are genuinely happy to work with you.
cons:
Although the pay is untaxed it's difficult to get enough hours (only a maximum of 20 hours) for a "living wage".
You're only contracted for the academic year and have to reapply for each subsequent year.

pros: Good for students who have some time to kill and want to contribute something to the school and help students
cons: May take up more time than it is worth.Grading fairly can be very time intensive and not worth grading.

pros: The staff is very friendly and they are willing to work around your school schedule. If you have a heavier schedule one quarter you can work less hours if you prefer more time for studying.
cons: The job can be kind of slow sometimes. During certain parts of the quarter there just isn't much to do

job_title: Web Engineer in San Lorenzo, CA
pros: Although not as good as an internship involved in the tech industry, getting a job for building a website with a professor is still good experience and gives you a feel on what client-developer relationship could be like.
cons: No cons, the hours are pretty flexible since you are allowed to work remote.

review_title: Great environment to work in and expand your leadership skills.
pros: Friendly and Inclusive Environment
cons:
Can sometimes change your responsibilities
Come up with schedules on a random basis

job_title: IT Student Assistant in Pomona, CA
pros: Nice staff, flexible work schedule, only work-intensive sometimes, nice coworkers
cons: Have to deal with mean and entitled faculty, sometimes coworkers get away with too much

pros:
Working with a diverse student body
Good location in a major metro area
CBA has a nice, new complex
Retirement is good (if it lasts!)
cons:
Ridiculous amounts of paperwork
Transfer to semesters = increase in faculty teaching load without increase in assistance
Sleepy faculty
Students are hit and miss in terms of quality and work ethic

pros: Good benefits, beautiful campus, most of the staff is highly engaged, work hard and truly care about their jobs
cons: Faculty in administrative positions support faculty no matter what.  If a faculty member complains about anything, rules are broken to placate them.  No accountability to ethics or regulations or laws because tax payers bear the cost of lawsuits.  Technology is decades behind the times.

review_title: Cal Poly Pomona Parking and Transportation Services
job_title: Community Service Officer in Pomona, CA
pros: Hours are flexible and student friendly also great for on campus students
cons: Don't get paid for over time also when people call out all other people suffer the consequences

pros:
Hours are mostly on weekends, leaving time for classes during the week.
Athletics department is full of nice folks who are always happy to help
Best views in the house when working games
cons: Weekend's can be destroyed when there's a lot of games being played

review_title: Great part-time job for a college student
pros:
- Flexible hours that adjust with your classes
- Working with people your age
- Supportive management that is there to help with anything
- Work independent from supervisors at certain offices
cons: - A lot of down time and we weren't allowed to work on homework in those times

pros:
- Became very familiar with the department policies.
- Had time to work on my homework.
- Was able to help other students which was very rewarding
cons:
- It was difficult to get more hours
- Sometimes work could get repetitive, such as filing papers, or putting together packets or folders

job_title: Lead Cashier in Cal Poly University, CA
pros: Flexible scheduling, some space to move up, lower management kind and willing to teach
cons: High turnover, no possibility of pay increase large gap between upper management and majority of the workforce no room to move up

review_title: Lots of work opportunities for students
pros: Many opportunities for students to work part time on campus. For the most part, supervisors are very understanding  and flexible about scheduling work with classes.
cons: Little transparency at the highest levels of administration gives the appearance of lack of interest in student well-being

job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Pomona, CA
pros: Free tuition, as well as supportive tenured faculty.
cons: Cutbacks during the 2007-2008. The dean of the College of Science is not the best and somewhat out of touch with the departments.

review_title: Good experience and wonderful working and student relationships
pros: Great faculty, students and staff.  Very good benefits
cons: Management does not communicate well to staff and there are not enough opportunities for growth.  Difficult to move through salary range

pros: Worked around school schedule and was very flexible. They also close for holidays so students can go home.
cons: The pay was not the best when you consider all the other expenses a student has.

pros: Great price for education however limited class selection which means you have the same teachers for multiple subjects
cons: A commuter school which means there aren’t that many activities. Food court has limited choices

pros: You get good experience without needing to drive far from your classes
cons: They pay is not great, but it is a student job, so what do you expect.

pros: employees are amazing, opportunities for growth. Very flexible schedule around school. Got scholarships to obtain extra certifications for professional/personal development.
cons: Had to pay for car parking during summer without discount even though others got discounts

review_title: my experience was a rollercoaster with ups and downs
pros: flexible schedule, convenient travel, overall a good work environment.
cons: biased management, they hire a lot of unprofessional students to work.

pros: The students are amazing, and the work we get to do is incredibly fulfilling.
cons: At such a large institution, it is important to be intentional about getting to know staff and faculty from other departments.

pros:
I worked at the College of Business as a student assistant for the summer.
- Friendly bosses
- Work environment was pretty chill
- Working with other students kept the job fun
cons: - Could be better hours

job_title: I&IT Student Assistant in Pomona, CA
pros: Provides hands on learning. Flexible hours and accommodates the student's schedule.
cons: As much as the downside of working here, there's really nothing much I can say. As a student assistant, I think everything is alright.

pros:
Work on your own schedule.
Work at your own pace.
Work from anywhere.
Easy work.
cons:

review_title: Great place to work for students

cons: They don't give raises been working there over a year

job_title: Front Desk Assistant in Pomona, CA

cons: The RA's are young and jump to conclusions too often

review_title: Cal Poly had prepped me for the "real world" through it's learn by doing philosophy. Great teachers and people.

pros: The students are our greatest assets and worth all effort.
cons: The politics and lack of funding for necessary capital improvements and faculty support and salaries

pros: Working closely with administrative staff and faculty department heads across the university
cons: Being the lowly grunt standing there being blamed for something your lead is responsible for.

pros: Great to work with students...
cons: Poor training and support lead to frustration when trying to do one's job.

pros: The HR department is filled with fun, genuine and eccentric personalities.
cons: everything is a little outdated, still does paper applications, need to switch to digitalizing everything.

pros: Easy to fit work schedule between classes. Management, secretaries, and HR are very helpful
cons: Pay was based on whatever the school had left
